musicalAnalysis.overview: Back in Black is AC/DC's quintessential hard rock anthem, featuring Brian Johnson's debut with the band. The song showcases the Malcolm Young/Angus Young dual guitar approach with simple but effective power chord progressions and memorable melodic hooks.

chordProgression.description: Classic rock progression with characteristic bVII chord giving it the AC/DC edge
Simple I-IV movement typical of AC/DC's straightforward approach
Classic I-IV-V-I progression, the backbone of rock music

scales.name: E Minor Pentatonic
scales.usage: Primary scale for lead guitar work and solos

techniques.name: Power Chords
techniques.description: The foundation of AC/DC's sound - two-note power chords with perfect fifth intervals

tips: Mute unused strings with fretting hand
Use downstrokes for authentic AC/DC tone
Practice clean chord changes at slow tempo

techniques.name: Palm Muting
techniques.description: Essential percussive technique using the palm to dampen strings for tight, punchy rhythm

tips: Rest palm edge lightly on strings near bridge
Don't press too hard - strings should still ring
Alternate between muted and open for dynamics
Practice with a metronome for tight timing
details.progression: Palm muted E5 - Open A5 - Palm muted E5

sections.name: Intro
sections.description: Iconic opening riff that immediately establishes the song's driving energy
notes: Let each chord ring briefly before the next

sections.name: Verse
sections.description: Brian Johnson's vocal entrance over palm-muted power chords
notes: Palm mute the E5 chords for percussive effect
Let A5 ring more openly for contrast

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: The anthemic 'Back in Black' hook with full power chord progression

sections.name: Guitar Solo
sections.description: Angus Young's signature pentatonic solo with characteristic bends and vibrato

Practice chord changes with click track
